text:
22floz bottle, BOD 06.15.2016, paid $5, poured into a tulip glass. As an American who drinks mostly Americanized versions of Belgian or French style ales, it is difficult to discern what makes a saison a saison and a farmhouse ale a farmhouse ale. Ill review as compared to those Ive had as defined as this style, and styles that are in a similar vein. 

Appears school bus yellow and aroma is like Juicy Fruit brand bubblegum. Heavy and phenolic - floral, orange zest, and aspirin flavors. It has some good and some bad, so sure its okay.

Bomber BOTTLED ON 6/15/16. Nose is explosively fruity, candyish, dusty powdery candy like Fun Dip and Smarties, tries to fill the room. But also a lots of Brett, white grape, honey, pepper, orange, subtle pineapple. Pour clear rich golden with abundant carbonation and a large, soapy off-white head. Taste lightly tart, lightly bitter, bit too much alcohol showing, not too sweet but gets an unnecessary boost from the oily-fruity notes, feels like it will cloy if one goes too fast. Very oily medium body, swishable but with a slight paucity of malt (though still fuller than my Brett beers!), firm spicy prickle throughout, and that persistent Bretty wildness. Musty-damp is there but low-profile, about the same as the cherry lining, at least until strength is gained in the finish. Bubblegum, touch of berry cough drop, very faint vegetal. Alcohol never burns but dulls things a bit, also eventually integrates dangerously. A fun one, but Id rather split this volume. [2017.04.07: 3.6]
Large bottle. Smells wonderful, seriously maybe best aroma ever. Taste good but funk gets to ya after awhile. Good stuff overall
Una raresa compartida al olut club de cata, es saison de guarda amb brets i mes de 9%, dolça i àcida, rara.
Provada al Club de Cata Olut Sabadell, aroma a plàtan tot i ser àcida curiosa
Club de cata en el Olut. Citrico en nariz. Banana en el gusto. Muy curiosa.
Club cata Olut. Aromas ácidos , en boca banana, pese a ser una saison. Muy curiosa.

Bottle shared in NYC. Pours clear or age-gold with a frothy, white head. The nose has bready malts, a little honey and caramel. Medium sweet flavour with lightly toasted malts, dry caramel, faint orange, a little cereal, hints of alcohol. Medium bodied with massaging carbonation. Great balance in the sweet, if sweet as per style, with further toasted cereal, graham crackers, toasted caramel, bready malts. Quite enjoyable.

Labeled on Rate Beer as bière de garde, on the label as saison ale brewed with French saison yeast and Brettanomyces. The label also notes that it is a Smuttlabs product. Lots of quick, beige foam that persists. Pours a dark cloudy amber, almost orange. Lots of spice and yeast in the nose with some strong vinous notes. The taste brings out the bright yeast and spice and a touch of melon fruit and green apple. Medium body with active fizz and a good dry finish. Very faint mineral notes, but the strongest flavors are vinous. Some sweetness comes out as it warms up and some slickness to the texture. The alcohol is muted in the flavor but catches up quickly. Far more interesting beer than their Hayseed saison. It almost seems a little too sophisticated for a saison, but very good in any case.

A very pretty hazy golden hue with lasting bone-white cap. Nose is funk-first, with cracked pepper and a background of lemon zest. Flavor thankfully has some sweet bready malt, though it fades to a semi-bitter blend of pepper and funk. Fairly smooth, and a decently clean finish. I might get into it by the bottom of the bottle, but this things a bit too wild for me.

Pour a translucent yellow with white head that leaves lacing. 
the nose is faint cirus. Body is medium. Taste is light sweet malt with light bitterness. 22 oz bottle Bottled: 6/15/16
On tap at 2SP Wilmington. Amber orange color. Tart barnyard aroma. Some tart orange flavor with a bit of barnyard funk. Dry mouthfeel yet still sweet. I was liking this.
Draft sample at the source. The beer is a hazed gold with a white head of foam. Some fruity notes, juicy sweetness. Dry sweet taste. A bit papery. Big body and medium carbonation.

Golden yellow color; hazy. A big head that never quite fully goes away. Looks like a big old school lager youd drink at a pool table at in a 1970s movie.

Ooooh the aroma! Grains of paradise, prickly and grassy; mint leaf. Inviting and terrific. Elements of buttery shortbread. This smells incredible.

Flavor is first apple juice, then it becomes basement funk, horseblanket, mint leaf, bubblegum, bitter grass. Some sulfurics like steamed broccoli.

The feel is prickly; dances on the tongue. This is a very nice beer with a lot of very interesting flavors. Not "easy to drink," per se, but very pleasant.
Whym, Portsmouth tap: pours orange with a white head. Aroma is bubblegum, yeast and lihht booze. Taste is kind of sweet. Typical biere de garde taste throughout. Not bad for what it is.

Thin wisp of foam frm the pour which disappears very quickly. Sour fruit, tart grapes, oranges and straw in the aroma. Color is a hazy muddy orange. Flavor is solid malt up front with a bit of sweetness, dandelion greens, lemon grass, a very slight sourness and unripe bananas. Light alcohol presence. A bit of pasty malts linger along with just a hint of tartness that makes the mouth beg for more. A very easy drinking brew that is light on the bret but big on flavor. Two thumbs up!

Tallahassee. Fl - Market Square Liquors - 22 oz bomber. Sparkling medium copper pour, prominent soft off-white head that fades after a while. Fruity, full bodied earthy aroma with hints of toffee, melons, some herbal, spicy essence that is hard to pin down, but enjoyable. Solid flavor, some spicy notes, some caramel sweetness, some raw cake mix, pears and butterscotch and a back end of vanilla. Thick, sticky mouthfeel. Pretty solid effort from Smuttynose.

Sampler at hayseed. Pours golden with a white head. Doesn't leave much lacing in the glass. Solid Brett notes on the nose. Certainly a nice blending of Brett and funk notes on the tongue. Hides it's booze very well. Finished clean. Maybe my favorite beer of the night so far. 

---Rated via Beer Buddy for iPhone

Bottle date of 06/15/16.
This was poured into a tulip.
The appearance was a soft hazy orange color with a slight transparency about it. Fingers worth of white foamy head quickly dies off. No lacing.
The smell starts off with some sweet cherries, light breadiness. Herbal sweetness. Sweet grass/somewhat like sage. Honey, and sweet lemon pulp.
The flavor was basically the same with a big herbal sweetness running into the aftertaste and finish.
On the palate, this one sat about a light to medium on the body with a semi-syrupy texture about it. Herbal sweetness wants to cling but softly slides on my tongue.
Overall, not a bad biere deGarde by an American brewer though most American brewers tend to get the Mouthfeel in these slightly sticky, hmmm....maybe again.

From the 650 ml. bottle dated 06/15/16. Golden-orange amber pour. Little to no head. Aroma of Belgian yeast, toasted bread crust, sourdough, herbs, and Brett-like sour notes. No booze. Medium body. Given the aroma I thought it would be far more sour and tart than it ended up tasting. But no - more a of mild sweetness with toasted bread and a spicy finish. Alcohol well integrated.

Bottle, from Cary Whole Foods. Good aroma. Sweet and Brett. Fruity yeasty. On the citrus side, orange. Mild Brett. Clean golden orange color, ok head, little to no lace. Moderate Sweet flavor. Heavy body, thick creamy oily mouthfeel, sweet dry finish. Solid offering from Smutty. Flavor best part, IMO
user_location: the Containment Area, North Carolina, USA

text: Pours a hazy orange with white head. A strong orange, fruit, yeast, and wheat aroma. A sweet flavor to start with orange and fruits, but turns a bit about and dry from pine, spices, yeast, malts, and wheat.

Draft at Dutchs from notes. Pours a hazy golden/light orange color with a medium sized off white head. The aroma and flavor had Belgian yeast, brett, citrus notes, peppery spice, additional fruit character, straw, mild funk, kind of surprised that this is 9%, decent enough.
Pours hazy gold into a tulip. White head with little retention recedes to hug rim. Clove and banana aromas. Sharp with sweet clove and banana front to back. No hint of Brett.

Bottle at home. Big malt flavor of caramel and sweet fruit, with a little bit of Brett character, but not much. Surprisingly uninteresting, considering how high the ABV is and the Brett fermentation. Would be interesting to try in a year or two.

[ Bottle ][ 1oz ][ @tasting ][ $0 ][ Shot glass ][ 08.15.15 ]hazy gold, thin white ring. Estery nose, lightly peppery with green notes. Sweet, cloying front palate, bubblegum ester, oily all over with heavy sugar from under-attenuation. A BdG at 9.1% shouldve told me something.

It is cloudy orange in color with a white head. It has aromas of yeast, caramel malts, basement, and leather. It has flavors of yeast, sweetness, oranges, earthly elements. and a bit of leather. It is moderately bitter on the palate with some sour elements.

cloudy yellow orange pours thick. Aroma honey, barley, orange. Tastes rich honeyed barley that goes toe to toe with the big 9.1%. Harmonious and punchy but a bite simple. A solid example of a style thats not my favorite. Some wheaty tannins and classic saison yeast flavor that is somewhat exapned upon. Some funk, but its just a hint of dusty funk so far..

Draft at Snallygaster 2015. Poured a hazy amber color with a small off-white head. Aroma was tart cherries, light sour notes. Some funky notes, light sour cherries, touchy funky on the finish. Alcohol is hard to find, which makes this a bit dangerous.
Draft. Hazy light amber body atop large off-white head. Aroma is moderately sweet, sour cherry, light orange. Taste is moderately sweet, orange, light sour cherry, funk. Medium body, some stickiness.

375 ml corked and caged from Buy Rite, 9/1/15. Bottled May 2015. 

Hazy orange color with a fizzy / frothy off white head. Good lacing on the glass. Very nice Saison yeast aroma, with some peppery notes. It has a bit of a mineral component as well. Theres definitely a bretty dryness here in both the flavor and the mouthfeel, but otherwise, I dont get much else from the brett. This turned out quite nice. Dangerous at 9.1%. Holy crap, Batman! This is one way to get the farmers from satiated to hammered before noon. Definitely not a working class thirst quencher at 9.1%
draft at Blue Monk, Buffalo NY, not my favorite of the series, kind of bland, perhaps the biere de garde is too lightly flavored to make this real funky, fruity yeastm, mild funk & brett

Orange beer with little white head (seems to be a trend this evening). That being said, this mouthfeel is awesome. Lots of carbonation. Very saison-esque. Tastes like a lightly bretted saison even though it has no brett in it. Id buy another if its easily available.

375. oooh a bier de garde tick! hazy orange, no head at all. hard to even get the cork out. Aroma is more saison like with a bit more sweetness .pepper, herbs, spice... great mouthfeel. really explodes. good pepper, honey, a little sour tart aspects. might age really well.
Draft at the growler nyc. Medium tan colo with a yeasty bready taste. Very nice flavor and the booze is balanced

May 2015 bottle, drunk 8/24/15.A lovely chestnut-auburn colored beer with a large but quickly receding off-white head. Good clarity.LOTS of Belgian Strong Golden-like esters and phenols in the nose...pineapple, banana, clove, vanilla and a slight raw/grainy alcohol edge to it. Not much in the way of brett...dont get much more than a bit of lime-like tartness/acidity. Some light caramel, toasted malt and bread dough round out the malt side of things.Quite dry in the mouth, with a grainy/watery texture, though somewhat ameliorated by the natural carbonation. Unfortunately, I find the yeast character to be pretty raw/crude and harsh. Mixing with the alcohol, its not so much raw ethanol as much as it is warming, drying, sharp fruit-like notes. Just seems like an Americanized Belgian-ale with little class or elegance. Dont get any Biere de Garde yeast notes that Ive ever had, nor do I get much in the way of malt. Off to the drain!

Draft. Poured cloudy yellow color with an average fizzy white head that was mostly lasting with fair lacing. Moderate yeast and citrus aroma. Medium body with a smooth texture and soft carbonation. Moderate sweet flavor with a medium smooth sweet finish of moderate duration. Good drinkable beer.

On tap at Giant Eagle in Grandview: yellow gold big white head that recedes quickly. aroma of belgian yeast and spice. tastes citrus, wheat, earthy, brett, little salt. easy drinking. thinnish palate. 7.4

Light florals and some coriander. Good balance, really like this one. Pours orange with good head and lacing. Light citrus. Great balance. Easy drinking and light tasting for high alcohol. Tap at Galaxy Hut.

From a 22 oz bottle at the WWWW RB tasting it is a cloudy golden color with an off white head.the aroma is bubblegum and the taste is slight bitter sweet taste that is typical of a saisson rather nice.
Bottle at the RateBeer WWWW Tasting. Hazy orange with off-white head. Aromas of funk, citrus, stone fruit. Tastes of funk, herbs, spice, stone fruit, citrus. Medium-light body with a dry finish.
From a 22 oz bottle at the WWWW RB tasting. Pours a cloudy gold with an off white head. Herbal nose. Favors of corriander and belgian yeast.
Bottle. Cloudy pale yellow color. Aroma of herbal hay. Taste is peppery dusty lemon, hay and straw.

Bottle at home Friday evening. Hazy orange yellow sudsy head. Nose is spice, tropical fruit, h t of cheesy funk. Tastes of pineapple juice, banana, black pepper, yeast, cheese, hay, some wood. High carbonation lively palate. Lingering pepper spice and farm. Enjoyable.

On tap at Dutchs. Totally hazy golden orange color. Pours with a bigger white head, that fades to a nice thin amount. Leaves a bunch of somewhat loose spoltches of lace. Nice bright belgian yeast, some citrus, mild spice, bit of pepper. Mild to moderate sweet taste, light bitter. Alcohol is pretty well hidden for 9%, drinks very smooth. Mild tang. Lighter body for that ABV too. Medium-plus body. Smooth, kind of soft, lighter carbonation. Mild slick. Nice funky finish. Tasty brett biere de garde.

375 mL bottle from Beer Run. Murky orange, large foamy white head, decent retention. Aroma of strong yeast and brett, almost funk, cheese, leather, bready malts, dry stone fruits. The taste is strong spicy yeast, pale malt, citrus, stone fruits, bretty finish. Medium bodied, bristly carbonation, no noticeable booze, lingering juicy fruits. Solid beer.
Bottle->tulip. Hazy gold with huge fluffy white head. A: yeast, slight funk, coriander, bread, banana. T: yeast, coriander, banana, spice. No funk. Eh.

Bottle from Julios. Cloudy orange with fizzy head. Mild farmhouse funk aroma with bready pastry spice grass and floral. Quite sweet peachy fruity with mild funk woody finish. Nearly flat after carbo fizzes away. Medium light body for abv. Forgettable.

Draft at the new brewery. Pours hazy gold with a thick white head. Tastes earthy, bready, and peppery with a hint of funk, banana, and dry oak. Smells like slightly sour wheat, pepper, lots of yeast, and straw. Medium body and carbonation.

Bottle shared last night at the meeting.
Hazy light golden color. Earthy bready peppery with just a touch of funk. Nice beer, but the Smuttwater was much more interesting.
Taster at the source. Pours orange gold with a white head. Aroma is slightly sour wheat, pepper, phenols. Flavor is a bit of banana up front, then dry, oak and pepper.

Draft at the Brewery. Hazy gold thicker head. Aroma is lots Belgain yeast, straw and pepper. Body is medium with a nice dry texture. The yeast is displayed very well with the Brett really, really subtle. Maybe served to cold. But they didnt go nuts with the Brett. Very nice.
